info.title: Disclaimer
info.content: This App is intended for professional use only. In no circumstances should it be used as an official guideline in management of congenital upper limb and hand differences. User discretion is advised.

info.title: Key Features and Functionality
info.content:
1) The App currently resembles the 2017 OMT Classification. 

2) You can search for a condition by scrolling down the OMT App as per normal or you can search for it by typing in the name of the condition.

3) Searching with Key Words - For those who are not familiar with the scientific terms of a condition, you may search with key words. For example, if you see a patient with fused fingers, you may search for the word 'fused' and a list of conditions associated with syndactyly will be shortlisted for you. The Glossary page (on the bottom right hand side) is here to aid you, as it contains a list of commonly used key words. 

4) Classification - Every condition in the OMT App will have a Classification section. If you click on 'Classification', you will be able to see the developmental axis that is involved. We believe frequent usage of this function will allow one to be familiar with the OMT Classification. 

5) Images & X-Rays - If you click on a condition, you will be able to see an image as well as an X-Ray of the condition (slide right/left to change between images). Please note that not every condition have images yet. 

6) Extra categories for Syndromes - The fourth and final part of the OMT is Syndromes. We have added extra categories for each Syndrome due to its unique characteristics. If you click on Syndrome, you will be able to see the hallmark features which gives a short description of the typical characteristics of the syndrome. You can also see the suggested genetic etiology behind the syndrome as well as the upper limb differences that are commonly associated with the condition. 

7) Tutorial Video - We have produced a tutorial video on how to maximise your use of this App. It is located on the bottom right hand side of this page.

labels: Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Disproportionate shortening of the upper limb with shortening of fingers

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Condition characterised by shortened upper limb with nubbins or remnant digits. Rudimentary nub-bins may be present which could include elements of the nail plate, bone, and cartilage. In addition the arm or forearm can also be shortened or displays abnormal development. Typically associated with Poland syndrome (see condition listed below)

info.title: Credits
info.content: Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Congenital condition typically defined by absence of the sternal part of the pectoralis major muscle on affected side. Numerous other associated congenital abnormalities of the affected upper limb including symbrachydactyly of the hand.

info.title: Credits
info.content: Courtesy of Mr. Wee Lam, Consultant Plastic and Hand Surgeon.

I-A-1-ii-b.title: Whole limb affected excluding Poland Syndrome
tags: Whole limb affected excluding Poland Syndrome

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Any unspecified congenital condition in which symbrachydactyly of the hand is present with associ-ated forearm/arm abnormalities, but without features of Poland Syndrome

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Condition where all elements of the upper limb beyond a certain level are absent, and there is ef-fectively an amputation at this level. It can be sub-classified based on the level of deficiency as listed in the conditions below. Note: presence of remnants such as nubbins beyond the level of deficiency suggests a diagnosis of sym-brachydactyly rather than transverse deficiency.

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Complete congenital absence of upper limb

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Growth arrest of the upper limb beyond the level of the clavicle or scapula

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Growth arrest of the upper limb beyond the level of the humerus ie absent elbow. Can be  at any level along the length of the humerus

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Growth arrest of the upper limb beyond the level of the forearm ie below the elbow

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Growth arrest of the upper limb at the level of the wrist. May have complete absence of carpal bones, at level of the proximal carpal bones or at level of the distal carpal bones. The forearm/arm is also involved

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Growth arrest of the upper limb at the level of the metacarpals. The forearm/arm is also usually involved

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Growth arrest of the upper limb at the level of the phalanges. May affect the proximal, middle or dis-tal phalanges. The forearm/arm is also involved

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: A condition where a segment of the upper limb is absent (arm/forearm) with a remnant hand. The segments missing can be at various levels as listed in the conditions below.

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Short forearm directly attached to trunk with absence of proximal upper limb

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Short humerus attached to hand with absence of forearm

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Hand directly attached to trunk with absence of arm and forearm

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Extremely rare condition where the entire limb is duplicated or triplicated

labels: Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb

I-A-2-i.title: Radial Longitudinal Deficiency – Thumb hypoplasia (with proximal limb involvement)
tags: Radial Longitudinal Deficiency – Thumb hypoplasia (with proximal limb involvement)

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Spectrum of upper limb abnormalities where the radial part of the upper limb does not form proper-ly: e.g., radial aplasia (radial club hand) with an associated thumb hypoplasia (shortend or smaller thumb). Associated with Fanconi’s anaemia, Holt-Oram Syndrome, VACTERL association and TAR syndrome. Sub-classification radius (Bayne & Klug): I (shortened radius <2mm); II (shortened radius missing distal epiphysis; III (shortened radius missing proximal epiphysis); IV (absent radius) Sub-classification thumb (Blauth): I (smaller thumb); II (unstable MCP joint); III (A&B depending on CMC joint); IV (floating thumb); V (absent thumb)

info.title: Credits
info.content: Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Spectrum of upper limb abnormalities where the ulna does not form properly resulting in a short-ened forearm with an ulnarly deviated hand and abnormal carpal bones. Compared to radial longi-tudinal deficiency, the elbow is more severely affected. Abnormalities of the hand are common, with usually absent digit. The thumb can also be affected. Also known as ulnar club hand.

info.title: Credits
info.content: Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Rare condition characterised by duplication of forearm with hand involvement. The radial ray is usually absent, with duplication of the ulna. Involvement of the hand would include duplicated ulna carpal bones, metacarpals and phalanges resulting in a symmetric polydactyly. Also known as Mirror Hand.

info.title: Credits
info.content: Case courtesy of Dr Rupesh Namdev, Radiopaedia.org, rID: 27331

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Spectrum of abnormalities which are characterised by an abnormal connection of the proximal radius and ulna at birth. Typically presents with absent forearm pronation and supination.

info.title: Credits
info.content: Case courtesy of Dr Hani Salam, Radiopaedia.org, rID: 13040

I-A-2-v.title: Congenital Dislocation of the Radial Head
tags: Congenital Dislocation of the Radial Head

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Almost always a posterior dislocation of the radial head, often combined with bowing and shorten-ing of the ulna and abnormalities of the radial head. Most common congenital abnormality of the elbow.

info.title: Credits
info.content: Case courtesy of Dr Maulik S Patel, Radiopaedia.org, rID: 14012

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Rare condition in which the elbow is held in fixed flexion due to abnormal connection between the humerus and radius. It can exist with, or without ulnar longitudinal dysplasia.

info.title: Credits
info.content: Case courtesy of Dr Ayaz Hidayatov, Radiopaedia.org, rID: 61776

labels: Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Dorsal-ventral axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Condition where palmar structures appear on the dorsal aspect of the hand or dorsal structures fail to develop (absent nails). The following syndromes are characterised by ventral dimelia.

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Dorsal-ventral axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Syndrome characterised by abnormal nail plates with associated abnormalities of the elbows, knees, pelvis, eyes and kidneys. Nail abnormalities range from complete absence or under-development to splitting or ridging. The elbow is often stiff with reduced supination/pronation. The patella may be absent or under-developed resulting in frequent dislocation

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Dorsal-ventral axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Condition characterised by absent or hypoplastic extensor/flexor muscles of the upper limb

labels: Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Unspecified axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Congenital malformation involving structures of the shoulder on an unspecified axis and can be further subclassified as follows

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Unspecified axis

info.title: Description
info.content: The affected scapula sits higher on the back than the normal contralateral one. Affected scapula is often underdeveloped and may be fused to the cervical spine. Most common shoulder abnormality in children and may be associated with Poland Syndrome.

info.title: Credits
info.content: Case courtesy of Dr Dalia Ibrahim, Radiopaedia.org, rID: 29259

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Unspecified axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Congenital abnormality of the shoulder musculature

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Unspecified axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Other abnormality of the shoulder which is neither Sprengel’s deformity or abnormal musculature only

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Unspecified axis

info.title: Description
info.content: A systemic condition characterised by congenital contractures of two or more joints. In the upper limb this is typically characterised by weak or absent elbow flexion, flexed wrists, multiple camptodactylys and clasped thumb. Can also involve other joints, especially the lower limbs.

info.title: Credits
info.content: Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Shortening of fingers due to shortened metacarpals or phalanges. Radiograph above shows short 5th metacarpal. Sub-classification: modified Bell’s A-E

info.title: Credits
info.content: Case courtesy of Dr Bahman Rasuli, Radiopaedia.org, rID: 63287

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Condition characterised by shortened upper limb with nubbins or remnant digits. Rudimentary nubbins may be present which could include elements of the nail plate, bone, and cartilage. Typically, the central digits are most affected with relative sparing of the border digits. In this case only the hand plate is affected with sparing of the arm and forearm. Also popularly known as ‘atypical cleft hand’.

info.title: Credits
info.content: Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Condition where all elements of the hand plate beyond a certain level are absent, and there is effectively amputation at this level. Note: presence of remnants such as nubbins beyond the level of deficiency suggests a diagnosis of symbrachydactyly rather than transverse deficiency. It is present at 3 levels within the hand plate, and thus can be further subdivided into 3 sub-sections.  IB1iii(a): Wrist (carpals absent/at level of proximal carpals/at level of distal carpals) IB1iii(b): Metacarpals IB1iii(c): Phalangeal (proximal/middle/distal)

I-B-2-i.title: Radial Deficiency (thumb – no forearm or arm involvement)
tags: Radial Deficiency (thumb – no forearm or arm involvement)

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: In the absence of forearm/arm involvement, this is also known as thumb hypoplasia. Present in a spectrum varying from small defects to complete absence of the thumb.  Sub-classification thumb (Blauth): I (smaller thumb); II (unstable MCP joint); III (A&B depending on CMC joint); IV (floating thumb); V (absent thumb). Photo above shows a Type V thumb hypoplasia.

info.title: Credits
info.content: Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: In the absence of forearm/arm involvement, it is characterised by a deficiency in ulnar-sided structures such as loss of ulnar digits and/or syndactyly

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Presence of an extra digit (or extra digits) on the radial side of the hand (preaxial), otherwise known as thumb duplication. It can vary from a barely visible skin tag to complete duplication or triplication of the thumb. It is the second most common congenital hand disorder. Further divided using Wassel classification.  Sub-classification: Wassel I-VI

info.title: Credits
info.content: Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Congenital malformation where the thumb has three phalanges instead of two and appears more like a finger than a thumb. The extra phalanx may be fully developed, rectangular or shortened and triangular shaped (delta phalanx). Triphalangeal thumbs can be opposable or non-opposable. Can be inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Classically known as Wassel VI thumb

info.title: Credits
info.content: Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh

I-B-2-v.title: Ulnar Dimelia (mirror hand - no forearm/arm involvement)

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Rare condition, also known as the mirror hand syndrome; characterised by duplication of ulna-sided digits and lack of radial-sided hand structures resulting in an absence of a thumb and ‘mirror-image’ polydactyly.  Sub-classification (Al-Qattan)

info.title: Credits
info.content: Case courtesy of Dr Jeremy Jones, Radiopaedia.org, rID: 24352

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Presence of an extra digit on the ulnar side of the hand (postaxial). Like radial polydactyly, the accessory digit may vary from a well-formed digit (Type A) to a small rudimentary nubbin (Type B)

info.title: Credits
info.content: Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Dorsal-ventral axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Presence of an ectopic palmar nail at the tip of the finger with evidence of dorsalisation of the palmar skin.

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Dorsal-ventral axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Appearance of palmar structures on the dorsal aspect of the hand. It can be further classified into three types (mild, moderate, and severe). Should only affect the hand plate to be classified here.

info.title: Credits
info.content: Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Unspecified axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Congenital fusion of two or more digits. Simple syndactyly: only confined to fusion of the soft tissues whereas complex syndactyly: involve osseous elements. Can be divided into complete (extends to fingertips) and incomplete

info.title: Credits
info.content: Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Unspecified axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Condition that causes one or more fingers to be permanently bent due to  a flexion deformity of the proximal interphalangeal joints (PIPJ). All of the volar structures are affected. The fifth finger is commonly affected and often bilateral.

info.title: Credits
info.content: Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Unspecified axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Also known as congenital clasped thumb. Due to a spectrum of extensor mechanism abnormalities, usually absent or weak extensor pollicis brevis (EPB), it is characterised by a flexed and adducted thumb deformity at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint. Can be associated with Arthrogryposis (Arthrogryposis Multiplex Congenita)

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Unspecified axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Arthrogryposis is defined as the presence of non-progressive congenital contractures of two or more joints. Distal arthrogryposis primarily involves the hand, typically characterised by deformities like camptodactyly and clasped thumb. Proximal striuctures such as the wrist or elbow are spared. Most commonly occurs bilaterally

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Unspecified axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Curvature of a digit in the plane of the palm (radioulnar), most commonly the little finger towards the ring finger. The middle phalanx of the little finger is underdeveloped for clinodactyly, instead of being rectangular, is wedge-shaped (delta phalanx) causing an angulation towards the plane of the palm

info.title: Credits
info.content: Case courtesy of Dr Mark Holland , Radiopaedia.org, rID: 23338

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Unspecified axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Progressive curvature of the distal phalanx of the 5th digit in a radial and palmar direction (cf Clinodactyly)

info.title: Credits
info.content: Case courtesy of Dr Michael Sargent, Radiopaedia.org, rID: 6040

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Unspecified axis

info.title: Description
info.content: This condition is characterised by ankylosis/fusion of the joints. Mostly this affects the interphalangeal joints in the fingers. The metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints may be affected, although less commonly.

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Unspecified axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Syndactyly is the congenital fusion of two or more digits which may involve bone and soft tissue. Complex syndactyly is where adjacent fingers are connected via an osseous or cartilaginous union.

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Unspecified axis

info.title: Description
info.content: An uncommon condition characterised by the presence of both syndactyly (fusion of digits) and polydactyly (accessory digits). In the above radiograph, there is central synpolydactyly in the third web space.

info.title: Credits
info.content: Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Unspecified axis

info.title: Description
info.content: A central V-shaped cleft in the centre of the hand due to absence of one or more central digits. Occasional the cleft is either on radial side or less commonly little ulnar side of the hand. Cleft hand usually occur bilaterally, but they can also occur unilaterally. Sometimes called ectrodactyly. An under-developed or hypoplastic thumb may also be present as well as syndactyly.

info.title: Credits
info.content: Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Unspecified axis

info.title: Description
info.content: In complicated syndactyly, there are abnormal or accessory phalanges/metacarpals present. The digits may be fused at various levels and in no obvious patterns. All of the digits may be involved.

info.title: Credits
info.content: Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh

info.title: Description
info.content: Circumferential intrauterine rings or bands which constrict developed tissue resulting in soft tissue grooves. Can be associated with distal lymphoedema or even amputation. Most commonly affects distal extremities such as fingers, but can also affect limbs more proximally, such as the upper arm or forearm. Classification according to Patterson (Types I-IV).

info.title: Credits
info.content: Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh

info.title: Description
info.content: Also known as a type of stenosing tenosynovitis, it is a disorder characterised by the catching or locking of the involved digit. This is due discrepancy between the space beneath the flexor sheath pulleys and the underlying flexor of the involved digit. Most commonly affects the thumb with flexion at the interphalangeal joint (see photo above). Notta’s node may be palpable in the A1 pulley area (nodule in tendon)

info.title: Credits
info.content: Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh

info.title: Description
info.content: In the context of an entire upper limb, hemihypertrophy refers to the condition in which one limb or a part of one limb is larger than the other limb exceeding the natural variation between limbs.

info.title: Description
info.content: Describes any condition in which the flexor, extensor or intrinsic muscles of the entire upper limb, are abnormal in size, shape or course.

info.title: Description
info.content: This condition is characterised by an abnormally large digit(s) or part of digits due to overgrowth of bone and soft tissues. The clinical presentation may be static or progressive. The former refers to an abnormally large digit present at birth, but which grows slowly. Whereas the latter may grow rapidly at a disproportionate rate as the child grows older. May be part of a syndrome (see Syndromes section). Photo above shows static macrodactyly of the middle finger.

info.title: Credits
info.content: Courtesy of Mr. Wee Lam, Consultant Plastic and Hand Surgeon.

III-A-2-ii.title: Aberrant intrinsic muscles of the hand
tags: Aberrant intrinsic muscles of the hand

info.title: Description
info.content: Condition in which intrinsic muscles of the hand differ from their size, shape or course.

info.title: Description
info.content: Benign vascular tumour of the upper limb present at birth. Intramuscular or deep hemangiomas may not be visible on the skin surface. The majority undergo a period of rapid shrinkage over the first two years of life (rapidly involuting congenital hemangioma, RICH) however they may remain relatively static and visible (noninvoluting congenital hemangioma, NICH)

info.title: Credits
info.content: Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh

info.title: Description
info.content: Abnormality of the blood vessels of the upper limb. Can affect arteries, veins, capillaries or lymphatics and are broadly divided in high-flow and low-flow malformations. Unlike hemangiomas, malformations are often not noticed at birth but become more apparent later in life. Clinical picture is highly variable but often presents as a mass.

info.title: Credits
info.content: Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh

info.title: Description
info.content: Any other vascular abnormality of the upper limb which is neither a hemangioma or malformation. Includes Kaposiform and other hemangioendotheliomas, tufted angiomas and malignant vascular tumours (angiosarcomas).

info.title: Description
info.content: In the case of upper extremities, this is a condition where there are multiple neurofibromas (peripheral nerve sheath tumours) affecting the upper limb or hand. May be limited to the upper limb as a form of segmental neurofibromatosis or part of neurofibromatosis types 1 and 2.

info.title: Description
info.content: Other congenital nerve-derived tumours of the upper limb which are not neurofibromas. Includes schwannoma and malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumours (MPNST)

info.title: Description
info.content: Also known as calcifying aponeurotic fibroma. Distinctive soft tissue fibrous tumour with spotty calcification which usually presents as a painless mass. Typically occurs on the volar surface of the hands and feet in children and adolescents. Despite being a benign tumour, its potentially locally agressive nature and a high recurrence risk, may mimic a malignant process and malignant transformation has been described.

info.title: Description
info.content: Benign nodular proliferation of fibrous tissue which occurs almost exclusively on the dorsal and lateral aspects of the fingers and toes. Presents as an enlarging, pink nodule which is usually painless. Can be multiple or single nodule.

info.title: Credits
info.content: Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh

info.title: Description
info.content: Any other connective tissue tumour of the upper limb which is neither a juvenile aponeurotic fibroma or infantile digital fibroma.

info.title: Description
info.content: Presence of upper limb osteochondromas which are benign tumours of the growth plates comprising of both bone and cartilage. Results in  multiple benign osteocartilaginous masses (exostoses) in relation of the end of long bones of the upper limbs such as the humerus and forearm bones. Types include hereditary multiple exostoses and synovial osteochondromatosis.

info.title: Description
info.content: Presence of multiple enchondromas in metaphyseal bone, particularly the small bones of the hands and feet. It is also known as ‘Ollier's Disease’. Due to effects on the growth plate, the affected limb may be shortened and/or bowed.

info.title: Credits
info.content: Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh

info.title: Description
info.content: Benign condition in which abnormal fibrous tissue replaces bone. Although the majority of patients may be asymptomatic, pathological fractures, bone pain and deformity may occur. May affect a single bone or multiple bones of the upper limbs (and elsewhere). Feature of McCune-Albright and Mazabraud syndromes.

info.title: Credits
info.content: Case courtesy of Dr Salman S. Albakheet, Radiopaedia.org, rID: 60893

info.title: Description
info.content: Conditions in which there is a skeletal deficiency due to abnormalities within the epiphyseal regions of the long bones of the upper limb. There can be a range of abnormalities that occur, such as failure to proliferate.

info.title: Description
info.content: Any other skeletal tumour of the upper limb which is neither an osteochondroma, enchondroma, fibrous dysplasia or an epiphyseal abnormality.
